<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Rihanna skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Rihanna</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-blp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-blp (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-blp</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox person (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox person</a>
<b>Robyn Rihanna Fenty</b> (born February 20, 1988), known by her stage name <b>Rihanna</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a><sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1">[1]</a></sup>), is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbadian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbadian people (page does not exist)">Barbadian</a> recording artist, actress, and fashion designer. She was born in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Michael,_Barbados" title="Saint Michael, Barbados">Saint Michael, Barbados</a>, and her career began when she met record producer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Sturken_and_Evan_Rogers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Sturken and Evan Rogers (page does not exist)">Evan Rogers</a> through mutual friends in late 2003 and recorded <a href="/wiki/Demo_(music)" title="Demo (music)">demo</a> tapes under Rogers's guidance. Her demo tape was sent to several record labels, and she subsequently signed a contract with <a href="/wiki/Def_Jam_Recordings" title="Def Jam Recordings">Def Jam Recordings</a> after auditioning for its president, rapper <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>. Her debut album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_the_Sun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of the Sun (page does not exist)">Music of the Sun</a></i> (2005) and its follow-up <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Girl_like_Me_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Girl like Me (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">A Girl Like Me</a></i> (2006) both peaked in the top ten on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a> chart. The albums spawned the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> top two hit single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pon_de_Replay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pon de Replay (page does not exist)">Pon de Replay</a>" and her first Hot 100 number-one "<a href="/w/index.php?title=SOS_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SOS (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">SOS</a>".
</p><p>Her third studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad</a></i> (2007), and its chart-topping lead single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Umbrella_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Umbrella (song) (page does not exist)">Umbrella</a>" were major breakthroughs in her career that brought her to widespread prominence. The album and its <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad:_Reloaded&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad: Reloaded (page does not exist)">Reloaded</a></i> version (2008) produced the worldwide hit singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Don%27t_Stop_the_Music_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Don't Stop the Music (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Don't Stop the Music</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_a_Bow_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take a Bow (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Take a Bow</a>", and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Disturbia_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disturbia (song) (page does not exist)">Disturbia</a>". The record was nominated for nine <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">Grammy Awards</a>, winning <a href="/w/index.php?title=Best_Rap/Sung_Collaboration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Best Rap/Sung Collaboration (page does not exist)">Best Rap/Sung Collaboration</a> for "Umbrella". Following a highly-publicized altercation with then-boyfriend <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chris_Brown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chris Brown (page does not exist)">Chris Brown</a>, she released her fourth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rated_R_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rated R (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Rated R</a></i>, in November 2009. It was followed by three more albums: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Loud</a></i> (2010), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Talk_That_Talk_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talk That Talk (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Talk That Talk</a></i> (2011), and her first <i>Billboard</i> 200 number one album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Unapologetic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unapologetic (page does not exist)">Unapologetic</a></i> (2012). That same year, she appeared in her first theatrical feature film, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Battleship_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battleship (film) (page does not exist)">Battleship</a></i>. Many of her songs rank among the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling singles (page does not exist)">best-selling singles</a> of all time, such as "Umbrella", "Take a Bow", "Disturbia", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Only_Girl_(In_the_World)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Only Girl (In the World) (page does not exist)">Only Girl (In the World)</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=S%26M_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="S&amp;M (song) (page does not exist)">S&amp;M</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (page does not exist)">We Found Love</a>", and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamonds_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamonds (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Diamonds</a>". In addition to her solo work, Rihanna has collaborated with numerous other artists, including being featured on the worldwide hits "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_Your_Life&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live Your Life (page does not exist)">Live Your Life</a>" (with <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>), "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_the_Way_You_Lie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love the Way You Lie (page does not exist)">Love the Way You Lie</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Monster_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Monster (song) (page does not exist)">The Monster</a>" (both with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eminem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eminem (page does not exist)">Eminem</a>).
</p><p>Rihanna is known for consistently reinventing her style and image, most notably since her third album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hebert_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hebert-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rihanna.27s_hairstyles_in_pictures_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rihanna.27s_hairstyles_in_pictures-3">[3]</a></sup> Her work has earned her numerous awards and accolades, including seven <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">Grammy Awards</a>,<sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_a"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://ec2-54-166-234-74.compute-1.amazonaws.com:8080/wiki/Rihanna#endnote_a">[1]</a></sup> eight <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Music Awards (page does not exist)">American Music Awards</a>, 22 <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Music_Awards" title="Billboard Music Awards" class="mw-redirect">Billboard Music Awards</a>, and two <a href="/w/index.php?title=BRIT_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BRIT Awards (page does not exist)">BRIT Awards</a>. She has sold over 30 million albums and 120 million singles worldwide, which makes her one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling artists</a> of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-Worldwide_sales_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Worldwide_sales-4">[4]</a></sup> She has achieved thirteen number one singles on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart, becoming the youngest and fastest solo artist to achieve the feat. <i>Billboard</i> named her the Digital Songs Artist of the 2000s decade and the top Hot 100 artist of the 2010s decade.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard1_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard1-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-billboard2_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard2-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hot1002010s_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hot1002010s-7">[7]</a></sup> In 2012, <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes_Magazine" title="Forbes Magazine" class="mw-redirect">Forbes</a></i> ranked her the fourth most powerful celebrity of the year, with earnings of $53 million between May 2011 and May 2012. The same year, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=TIME_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TIME (magazine) (page does not exist)">TIME</a></i> named Rihanna one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World.  On November 24, 2013, Rihanna was presented with the first ever American Music "Icon" Award.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bridgetown2.jpg" title="File:Bridgetown2.jpg">File:Bridgetown2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna grew up in the city of <a href="/wiki/Bridgetown" title="Bridgetown">Bridgetown</a>, Barbados.</div></div></div>
<p>Robyn Rihanna Fenty was born on February 20, 1988, in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Michael,_Barbados" title="Saint Michael, Barbados">Saint Michael, Barbados</a>. Her mother is Monica Braithwaite, a retired <a href="/w/index.php?title=Afro-Guyanese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Afro-Guyanese (page does not exist)">Afro-Guyanese</a> accountant, and her father is Ronald Fenty, a warehouse supervisor of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Barbadian_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Barbadian people (page does not exist)">Barbadian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">Irish</a> descent.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-People_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-9">[9]</a></sup> Rihanna has two brothers, Rorrey and Rajad Fenty, and two half-sisters and a half-brother from her father's side, each born to different mothers from his previous relationships.<sup id="cite_ref-ew_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> She grew up in a three-bedroom bungalow in <a href="/wiki/Bridgetown" title="Bridgetown">Bridgetown</a> and sold clothes with her father in a stall on the street. Rihanna's childhood was deeply affected by her father's addiction to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crack_cocaine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crack cocaine (page does not exist)">crack cocaine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alcohol" title="Alcohol">alcohol</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">marijuana</a>, and her parents' turbulent marriage ended when she was&#160;14.<sup id="cite_ref-People_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-People-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Biography_Today_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biography_Today-12">[12]</a></sup> Rihanna grew up listening to <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a> music and began singing at around the age of seven.<sup id="cite_ref-ew_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew-10">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> She attended Charles F. Broome Memorial Primary School and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Combermere_School_(Barbados)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Combermere School (Barbados) (page does not exist)">Combermere High School</a>, where she formed a musical trio with two of her classmates.<sup id="cite_ref-ew_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ew-10">[10]</a></sup> Rihanna was an army cadet in a sub-military programme; the <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">singer-songwriter</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shontelle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shontelle (page does not exist)">Shontelle</a> was her drill sergeant.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Although she initially wanted to graduate from high school, she chose to pursue a musical career instead.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2003.E2.80.9305:_Music_of_the_Sun">2003–05: <i>Music of the Sun</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RihannaJingle_Ball_cropped.jpg" title="File:RihannaJingle Ball cropped.jpg">File:RihannaJingle Ball cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=KIIS-FM_Jingle_Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KIIS-FM Jingle Ball (page does not exist)">Jingle Ball</a>, 2005</div></div></div>
<p>Rihanna's career began through her association with American record producers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Sturken_and_Evan_Rogers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Sturken and Evan Rogers (page does not exist)">Carl Sturken and Evan Rogers</a>; she met Rogers through mutual friends in Barbados in December 2003. She caught the attention of Rogers, who asked Rihanna to come to his hotel room, where she performed renditions of the songs "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Emotion_(Samantha_Sang_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emotion (Samantha Sang song) (page does not exist)">Emotion</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Hero_(Mariah_Carey_song)" title="Hero (Mariah Carey song)">Hero</a>". This impressed Rogers, who then took Rihanna and her mother to <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> to record some <a href="/wiki/Demo_(music)" title="Demo (music)">demo</a> tapes.<sup id="cite_ref-TheGuardian1_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheGuardian1-16">[16]</a></sup> Rihanna was signed to Rogers' and Sturken's production company, Syndicated Rhythm Productions, which assigned her a lawyer and manager. In late 2004, her demo tape was distributed to record labels around the world,<sup id="cite_ref-TheGuardian1_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheGuardian1-16">[16]</a></sup> where it captured the attention of Jay Brown, an A&amp;R executive at <a href="/wiki/Def_Jam_Recordings" title="Def Jam Recordings">Def Jam Recordings</a>, and played it for president and CEO of Def Jam, <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
In February 2005, Rihanna flew up to New York City to audition for Jay-Z and industry executive <a href="/wiki/L.A._Reid" title="L.A. Reid">L.A. Reid</a>, performing <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">Whitney Houston</a>'s version of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=For_the_Love_of_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="For the Love of You (page does not exist)">For the Love of You</a>" and the original songs "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pon_de_Replay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pon de Replay (page does not exist)">Pon de Replay</a>" and "The Last Time".<sup id="cite_ref-TheGuardian1_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheGuardian1-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-USAToday1_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday1-18">[18]</a></sup> That same day, Rihanna signed a six-album record deal with Def Jam Recordings, and she later moved to New York City to live with Rogers and his wife.<sup id="cite_ref-TheGuardian1_16-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheGuardian1-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RollingStone1_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RollingStone1-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna spent the next three months collaborating with rapper <a href="/wiki/Memphis_Bleek" title="Memphis Bleek">Memphis Bleek</a> on his fourth studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=534_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="534 (album) (page does not exist)">534</a></i> and recording her debut album.<sup id="cite_ref-Jay-Zpicks_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jay-Zpicks-20">[20]</a></sup> Her album featured production from Rogers, Sturken, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stargate_(production_team)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stargate (production team) (page does not exist)">StarGate</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poke_%26_Tone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poke &amp; Tone (page does not exist)">Poke &amp; Tone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SlantMag1_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlantMag1-21">[21]</a></sup> Her debut single, "Pon de Replay", was released in August 2005. It charted successfully worldwide, peaking in the top five in fifteen countries, including at number two on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> chart and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UK_Singles_Chart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UK Singles Chart (page does not exist)">UK Singles Chart</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BillChartS_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BillChartS-22">[22]</a></sup> Her debut album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_the_Sun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of the Sun (page does not exist)">Music of the Sun</a></i>, was released later that month. It peaked at number ten on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a> and received a gold certification from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA), denoting shipments of over 500,000 units.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAA-albums_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-albums-23">[23]</a></sup> The album sold over two million copies worldwide. It received mixed reviews; <i>Rolling Stone</i> gave it two and a half out of five stars and described as lacking replay value, ingenuity, and rhythm.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Sal Cinquemani of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slant_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slant Magazine (page does not exist)">Slant Magazine</a> described the album as a "glut of teen R&amp;B chanteuses" and described her lead single as "a dancehall-pop mixture that owes plenty of its sweat and shimmy to <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Baby_Boy_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Baby Boy (Beyoncé song)">Baby Boy</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-SlantMag1_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlantMag1-21">[21]</a></sup> A second single, "If It's Lovin' that You Want", was not as successful as its predecessor, but reached the top ten in Australia, Ireland, and New Zealand.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Besides music Rihanna made her acting debut in a <a href="/wiki/Cameo_appearance" title="Cameo appearance">cameo</a> role in the straight-to-DVD film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bring_It_On:_All_or_Nothing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bring It On: All or Nothing (page does not exist)">Bring It On: All or Nothing</a></i>, released in August 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-BringsOnActing_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BringsOnActing-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2006.E2.80.9308:_A_Girl_Like_Me_and_Good_Girl_Gone_Bad">2006–08: <i>A Girl Like Me</i> and <i>Good Girl Gone Bad</i></span></h3>
<p>A month after the release of her debut album, Rihanna began working on her second studio album.<sup id="cite_ref-HerRockSide_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HerRockSide-27">[27]</a></sup> Rogers, Sturken, StarGate, <a href="/w/index.php?title=J._R._Rotem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="J. R. Rotem (page does not exist)">J. R. Rotem</a> and label-mate singer-songwriter <a href="/wiki/Ne-Yo" title="Ne-Yo">Ne-Yo</a> worked on the production and writing of the album.<sup id="cite_ref-DoneCrying_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DoneCrying-28">[28]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Girl_like_Me_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Girl like Me (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">A Girl Like Me</a></i> was released in April 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> Critical response to the album was mixed; <i>Rolling Stone</i> commented, "Like her filler-packed debut album, this similar but superior follow-up doesn't deliver anything else as ingenious as its lead single."<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The album was a commercial success, charting in the top ten in thirteen countries. The album reached number one in Canada and number five in the UK and US, where it sold 115,000 copies its first week.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAA-albums_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-albums-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-acharts_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-acharts-31">[31]</a></sup> Its lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=SOS_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SOS (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">SOS</a>", was an international success, charting in the top five in eleven countries, including Canada, Germany, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom. The song reached number one on the US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 and in Australia, her first to reach this chart position.<sup id="cite_ref-SOSAcharts_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SOSAcharts-32">[32]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Unfaithful_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unfaithful (song) (page does not exist)">Unfaithful</a>", the album's second single, reached the top ten in eighteen countries, including number one in Canada and Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-UnfaithfulAcharts_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UnfaithfulAcharts-33">[33]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Ride&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Ride (page does not exist)">We Ride</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Break_It_Off&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Break It Off (page does not exist)">Break It Off</a>", the latter featuring <a href="/wiki/Sean_Paul" title="Sean Paul">Sean Paul</a>, were also released as singles.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Following the release of the album, Rihanna embarked on her first headlining tour, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rihanna:_Live_in_Concert_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rihanna: Live in Concert Tour (page does not exist)">Rihanna: Live in Concert Tour</a>, also performing alongside Jay-Z and Ne-Yo on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rihanna:_Live_in_Concert_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rihanna: Live in Concert Tour (page does not exist)">Rock Tha Block Tour</a>. In addition, she joined <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pussycat_Dolls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pussycat Dolls (page does not exist)">The Pussycat Dolls</a> on their <a href="/w/index.php?title=PCD_World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PCD World Tour (page does not exist)">PCD World Tour</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna-brisbane.jpg" title="File:Rihanna-brisbane.jpg">File:Rihanna-brisbane.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing at the <a href="/wiki/Brisbane_Entertainment_Centre" title="Brisbane Entertainment Centre">Brisbane Entertainment Centre</a>, 2008</div></div></div>
<p>For her third studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad</a></i>, Rihanna embraced a new musical direction through uptempo dance tracks produced by <a href="/wiki/Timbaland" title="Timbaland">Timbaland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Will.i.am" title="Will.i.am">will.i.am</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sean_Garrett" title="Sean Garrett">Sean Garrett</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LosesGoodImage_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LosesGoodImage-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-VoiceLessons_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VoiceLessons-37">[37]</a></sup> Released in May 2007, the album charted at number two in Australia and the US and topped the charts in multiple countries, including Brazil, Canada, Ireland, Japan, Russia and the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-GGGBcharts_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GGGBcharts-38">[38]</a></sup> The album received the most positive critical reviews of her first three albums.<sup id="cite_ref-metacritic_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-metacritic-39">[39]</a></sup> The lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Umbrella_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Umbrella (song) (page does not exist)">Umbrella</a>", topped the charts in thirteen countries and remained number one in the UK for ten consecutive weeks, the longest-running number one single since <a href="/wiki/Wet_Wet_Wet" title="Wet Wet Wet">Wet Wet Wet</a>'s single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_Is_All_Around_(The_Troggs_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love Is All Around (The Troggs song) (page does not exist)">Love Is All Around</a>" spent fifteen weeks at the top in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> It was Rihanna's first single to be named one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_singles_worldwide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling singles worldwide (page does not exist)">best-selling singles worldwide</a>, with sales of over 6.6 million copies.<sup id="cite_ref-ifpi2007_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ifpi2007-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> The songs "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Shut_Up_and_Drive_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shut Up and Drive (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Shut Up and Drive</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hate_That_I_Love_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hate That I Love You (page does not exist)">Hate That I Love You</a>" featuring Ne-Yo, and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Don%27t_Stop_the_Music_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Don't Stop the Music (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Don't Stop The Music</a>" were also released as singles. In support of the album, she began the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad Tour (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad Tour</a> in September 2007, with 80 shows across the US, Canada, and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Rihanna was nominated for several <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">2008 Grammy Awards</a>, winning Best Rap/Sung Collaboration for "Umbrella" alongside Jay-Z.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout 2008, Rihanna performed on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Glow_in_the_Dark_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glow in the Dark Tour (page does not exist)">Glow in the Dark Tour</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lupe_Fiasco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lupe Fiasco (page does not exist)">Lupe Fiasco</a>, and <a href="/wiki/N.E.R.D" title="N.E.R.D">N.E.R.D</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mtv_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtv-46">[46]</a></sup> Her third album's reissue, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad:_Reloaded&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad: Reloaded (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad: Reloaded</a></i>, was released in June 2008 with three new songs: "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Disturbia_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disturbia (song) (page does not exist)">Disturbia</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_a_Bow_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take a Bow (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Take a Bow</a>", and the <a href="/wiki/Maroon_5" title="Maroon 5">Maroon 5</a> duet "<a href="/w/index.php?title=If_I_Never_See_Your_Face_Again&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="If I Never See Your Face Again (page does not exist)">If I Never See Your Face Again</a>". All three were released as singles and charted highly, reaching peak positions worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> In August 2008, Rihanna and a host of other female singers, including <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_J._Blige" title="Mary J. Blige">Mary J. Blige</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a>, recorded the charity single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Just_Stand_Up!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Just Stand Up! (page does not exist)">Just Stand Up!</a>", the theme song to the anti-cancer campaign <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stand_Up_to_Cancer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stand Up to Cancer (page does not exist)">Stand Up to Cancer</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_Your_Life&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live Your Life (page does not exist)">Live Your Life</a>", a duet between <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a> and Rihanna, released that November, peaked in the top ten in thirteen countries worldwide, topping the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100.
</p><p>A remix album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad:_The_Remixes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad: The Remixes (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad: The Remixes</a></i>, was released in January 2009. <i>Good Girl Gone Bad</i> has sold over 2.8 million units in the United States alone, receiving a two-times-platinum certification from the RIAA. It is Rihanna's best-selling album in the country to date.<sup id="cite_ref-RIAA-albums_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RIAA-albums-23">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-May_2013_Sales_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-May_2013_Sales-51">[51]</a></sup> The album has sold over seven million copies worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2009.E2.80.9311:_Rated_R.2C_Loud_and_Talk_That_Talk">2009–11: <i>Rated R</i>, <i>Loud</i> and <i>Talk That Talk</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna.jpg" title="File:Rihanna.jpg">File:Rihanna.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, April 2010</div></div></div>
<p>In early 2009, Rihanna began working on her fourth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rated_R_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rated R (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Rated R</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> Meanwhile, she collaborated with Jay-Z and Kanye West on "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Run_This_Town&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Run This Town (page does not exist)">Run This Town</a>", the second single from Jay-Z's eleventh studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Blueprint_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Blueprint 3 (page does not exist)">The Blueprint 3</a></i>. The song peaked at number two on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100, and reached the top ten in ten other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-RTTcharts_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTTcharts-54">[54]</a></sup> <i>Rated R</i> was released in November 2009 with <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> stating that Rihanna "transformed her sound and made one of the best pop records of the year".<sup id="cite_ref-album2ew_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-album2ew-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rosen_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rosen-56">[56]</a></sup> The album's lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Roulette_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Roulette (song) (page does not exist)">Russian Roulette</a>", was a commercial success, reaching number one in Norway and Switzerland and making the top ten in sixteen other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-RRcharts_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RRcharts-57">[57]</a></sup> This was followed by the release of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hard_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hard (song) (page does not exist)">Hard</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Young_Jeezy" title="Young Jeezy">Young Jeezy</a> and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rude_Boy_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rude Boy (song) (page does not exist)">Rude Boy</a>". The latter was the biggest worldwide success from the album, topping the US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 for six weeks and reaching top ten positions in twenty-two other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-Hardcharts_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hardcharts-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-rudeboycharts_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rudeboycharts-59">[59]</a></sup> Two other singles were released from the album: "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rockstar_101&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rockstar 101 (page does not exist)">Rockstar 101</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Slash_(musician)" title="Slash (musician)">Slash</a> and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Te_Amo_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Te Amo (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Te Amo</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-rockstarcharts_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rockstarcharts-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-teamocharts_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-teamocharts-61">[61]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rated_R_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rated R (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Rated R: Remixed</a></i> was released in the spring of 2010 and featured ten tracks remixed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chew_Fu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chew Fu (page does not exist)">Chew Fu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> To promote the album, Rihanna embarked on her second worldwide tour, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Last_Girl_on_Earth_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Last Girl on Earth Tour (page does not exist)">Last Girl on Earth Tour</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-north_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-north-63">[63]</a></sup> At the <a href="/w/index.php?title=52nd_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="52nd Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">52nd Grammy Awards</a>, "Run This Town" won <a href="/w/index.php?title=Best_Rap_Song&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Best Rap Song (page does not exist)">Best Rap Song</a> and Best Rap/Sung Collaboration.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>In summer 2010, Rihanna collaborated with rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eminem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eminem (page does not exist)">Eminem</a> on "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_the_Way_You_Lie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love the Way You Lie (page does not exist)">Love the Way You Lie</a>", which was a major worldwide success, reaching number one in over twenty countries.<sup id="cite_ref-LTWYLcharts_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LTWYLcharts-65">[65]</a></sup> The song was Rihanna's seventh US number one of her career, making her the female artist with the fifth-most number ones in the chart's history.<sup id="cite_ref-BB-ReplacePerry_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BB-ReplacePerry-66">[66]</a></sup> Reaching number two, the song became the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_singles_by_year_(UK)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling singles by year (UK) (page does not exist)">biggest-selling song of 2010 in the UK</a>, and the first of Rihanna's singles to sell over one million copies in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-official_charts_end_of_2010_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-official_charts_end_of_2010-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> She also lent her vocals to "<a href="/w/index.php?title=All_of_the_Lights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All of the Lights (page does not exist)">All of the Lights</a>", a single from Kanye West's album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Beautiful_Dark_Twisted_Fantasy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy (page does not exist)">My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy</a></i>, alongside <a href="/wiki/John_Legend" title="John Legend">John Legend</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=The-Dream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The-Dream (page does not exist)">The-Dream</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elly_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elly Jackson (page does not exist)">Elly Jackson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Keys" title="Alicia Keys">Alicia Keys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fergie_(singer)" title="Fergie (singer)">Fergie</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kid_Cudi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kid Cudi (page does not exist)">Kid Cudi</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elton_John&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elton John (page does not exist)">Elton John</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rihanna.C2.A0.E2.80.94_All_Of_The_Lights_.28MTV.29_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rihanna.C2.A0.E2.80.94_All_Of_The_Lights_.28MTV.29-69">[69]</a></sup> In October 2010, Rihanna switched managers, joining Jay-Z's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roc_Nation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roc Nation (page does not exist)">Roc Nation</a> Management.<sup id="cite_ref-Rleaves_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rleaves-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna,_LOUD_Tour,_Minneapolis_6_crop.jpg" title="File:Rihanna, LOUD Tour, Minneapolis 6 crop.jpg">File:Rihanna, LOUD Tour, Minneapolis 6 crop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna in Minneapolis performing on her <a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud Tour (page does not exist)">Loud Tour</a>, June 2011</div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Loud</a></i>, Rihanna's fifth studio album, was released the following month.<sup id="cite_ref-NewLoud_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewLoud-71">[71]</a></sup> Its lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Only_Girl_(In_the_World)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Only Girl (In the World) (page does not exist)">Only Girl (In the World)</a>", reached number one in fifteen countries, including Australia, Canada, the UK, and the US.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> The album's second single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=What%27s_My_Name%3F_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="What's My Name? (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">What's My Name?</a>", featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a>, also reached number one in the US and UK, making Rihanna the first female solo artist to have five number one singles in the United Kingdom in consecutive years.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The song reached number one on the US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 before "Only Girl (In the World)", the first time in the chart's history that an album's lead single reached number one after the second.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> The third single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=S%26M_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="S&amp;M (song) (page does not exist)">S&amp;M</a>", reached number one in the US following the release of its official remix featuring <a href="/wiki/Britney_Spears" title="Britney Spears">Britney Spears</a>. It was Rihanna's tenth US number one single on the chart, tying her with <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet Jackson</a> in fourth place for female soloists who have topped the chart. With only four years, eleven months, and two weeks between her first and tenth number one on the chart, Rihanna set a record as the solo artist with the fastest accumulation of ten chart toppers.<sup id="cite_ref-.27S.26M.27Reigns_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-.27S.26M.27Reigns-77">[77]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Man_Down&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Man Down (page does not exist)">Man Down</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=California_King_Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California King Bed (page does not exist)">California King Bed</a>" were released as singles in May 2011 with moderate success.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheers_(Drink_to_That)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheers (Drink to That) (page does not exist)">Cheers (Drink to That)</a>" was released as the sixth and final single from the album, reaching the top twenty in the UK and the top ten in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2011, "Only Girl (In the World)" won the award for Best Dance Recording at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=53rd_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="53rd Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">53rd Grammy Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Grammy2011_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grammy2011-81">[81]</a></sup> In June 2011, Rihanna embarked on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud Tour (page does not exist)">Loud Tour</a>, which sold out ten nights at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_O2_Arena_(London)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The O2 Arena (London) (page does not exist)">The O<sub>2</sub> Arena</a> in <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, the most sold out shows for a female artist in the venue's history.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> The tour was the seventh highest grossing tour worldwide of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-PSP_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSP-84">[84]</a></sup> The final three shows in London in December 2011 were filmed for Rihanna's second live <a href="/w/index.php?title=Video_album&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Video album (page does not exist)">video album</a>, titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_Tour_Live_at_the_O2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud Tour Live at the O2 (page does not exist)">Loud Tour Live at the O2</a></i>, which was released on December 18, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> In October 2011, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicki_Minaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicki Minaj (page does not exist)">Nicki Minaj</a> released the collaboration "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fly_(Nicki_Minaj_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fly (Nicki Minaj song) (page does not exist)">Fly</a>", featuring Rihanna. The song peaked within the top twenty in the US and UK.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna's sixth album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Talk_That_Talk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talk That Talk (page does not exist)">Talk That Talk</a></i>, was released in November 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> The album debuted at number three on the <i>Billboard</i> 200 with sales of 198,000 copies<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> and number one in the UK, selling 163,000. The lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (page does not exist)">We Found Love</a>", topped charts in twenty-seven countries worldwide, peaking in the top ten in thirty countries and breaking many records worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-wflcharts_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wflcharts-91">[91]</a></sup> It topped the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> for ten non-consecutive weeks, becoming Rihanna's longest-running number one single and the longest-running number one of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-wflcharts2_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wflcharts2-92">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wflcharts3_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wflcharts3-93">[93]</a></sup> The song was later named the 24th biggest hit of all time on the <i>Billboard </i>Hot 100.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1">[1]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=You_Da_One&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="You Da One (page does not exist)">You Da One</a>" and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Talk_That_Talk_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talk That Talk (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">titular track</a> featuring Jay-Z were released as the second and third singles from the album to moderate success, the former reaching the top twenty in the UK and US.<sup id="cite_ref-You_Da_One_UK_chart_peak_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-You_Da_One_UK_chart_peak-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-You_Da_One_US_chart_peak_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-You_Da_One_US_chart_peak-95">[95]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Where_Have_You_Been&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Where Have You Been (page does not exist)">Where Have You Been</a>", the fifth single, successfully charted worldwide, reaching number five in the US and six in the UK.<sup id="cite_ref-USHot100July7Peak_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USHot100July7Peak-96">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-WHYBPeakUK_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WHYBPeakUK-97">[97]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Cockiness_(Love_It)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cockiness (Love It) (page does not exist)">Cockiness (Love It)</a>" was released as the album's sixth and final single in a remixed form featuring rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=ASAP_Rocky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASAP Rocky (page does not exist)">ASAP Rocky</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2012.E2.80.9313:_Acting_and_Unapologetic">2012–13: Acting and <i>Unapologetic </i></span></h3>
<p>In early 2012, two collaborations featuring Rihanna were released: Coldplay's "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Princess_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Princess of China (page does not exist)">Princess of China</a>" from the album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mylo_Xyloto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mylo Xyloto (page does not exist)">Mylo Xyloto</a></i> and Drake's "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_Care_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take Care (song) (page does not exist)">Take Care</a>" from his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Take_Care_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Take Care (album) (page does not exist)">album of the same name</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> In February 2012, Rihanna won her third <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap/Sung_Collaboration" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration">Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration</a> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">2012 Grammy Awards</a>, and was voted the Best International Female Solo Artist at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2012_BRIT_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2012 BRIT Awards (page does not exist)">2012 BRIT Awards</a> for the second consecutive year.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> March 2012 saw the simultaneous release of collaborations between Rihanna and Chris Brown: remixes of her song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Birthday_Cake_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birthday Cake (song) (page does not exist)">Birthday Cake</a>" and his "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Turn_Up_the_Music_(Chris_Brown_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turn Up the Music (Chris Brown song) (page does not exist)">Turn Up the Music</a>". The recordings received mainly negative responses due to the pair's history of domestic violence.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> In September 2012, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love_(video)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (video) (page does not exist)">We Found Love</a>" won the <a href="/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Video_of_the_Year" title="MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year">MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year</a>, making Rihanna the first woman to receive the accolade more than once.<sup id="cite_ref-2012_VMA_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2012_VMA-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna2012.jpg" title="File:Rihanna2012.jpg">File:Rihanna2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna at the Australian premiere of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Battleship_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battleship (film) (page does not exist)">Battleship</a></i> in April 2012</div></div></div>
<p>Rihanna starred as Petty Officer (GM2) Cora Raikes in her first theatrical feature film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Battleship_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battleship (film) (page does not exist)">Battleship</a></i>, which was released on May 18, 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> Loosely based on the <a href="/wiki/Battleship_(game)" title="Battleship (game)">game of the same name</a>, both the film and Rihanna's performance received mixed-to-negative reviews; <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> said she was "just fine in the rather generic role".<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> She received a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Supporting_Actress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress (page does not exist)">Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress</a><sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> and, on a more positive note, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Teen_Choice_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Teen Choice Award (page does not exist)">Teen Choice Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> She appeared in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Katy_Perry:_Part_of_Me&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Katy Perry: Part of Me (page does not exist)">Katy Perry: Part of Me</a></i>, a 3D documentary-concert film about singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Katy_Perry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Katy Perry (page does not exist)">Katy Perry</a>. On August 19, 2012, Rihanna appeared in the first episode of the second season of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oprah_Winfrey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oprah Winfrey (page does not exist)">Oprah Winfrey</a>'s American prime time television show <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Oprah%27s_Next_Chapter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oprah's Next Chapter (page does not exist)">Oprah's Next Chapter</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Oprah_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oprah-109">[109]</a></sup> The episode scored the second-highest ratings in the history of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oprah_Winfrey_Network_(U.S._TV_channel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel) (page does not exist)">Oprah Winfrey Network</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna's seventh studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Unapologetic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unapologetic (page does not exist)">Unapologetic</a></i>, was released in November 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> In the United States, the album debuted at number one on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a> with sales of 238,000, marking Rihanna's first number one album in the country. In addition, it was the best-selling debut week of her career, besting her fifth studio album <i>Loud</i> (2010).<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> The album was Rihanna's third consecutive number one album in the United Kingdom and fifth in Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-officialcharts.com_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-officialcharts.com-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> The lead single from the album, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamonds_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamonds (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Diamonds</a>", reached number one in more than twenty countries worldwide, including on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a>, her twelfth number one on the chart which tied her with Madonna and The Supremes as the artists' with the fourth most number ones on the chart's history.<sup id="cite_ref-Trust_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trust-115">[115]</a></sup> The album's second single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Stay_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stay (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Stay</a>", featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mikky_Ekko&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mikky Ekko (page does not exist)">Mikky Ekko</a>, reached the top five in over twenty countries, including number three on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pour_It_Up&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pour It Up (page does not exist)">Pour It Up</a>" was released as the second U.S. single and third overall, reaching number 19 on the Hot 100.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard.com_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard.com-117">[117]</a></sup> An official remix featuring American rappers Young Jeezy, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rick_Ross&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rick Ross (page does not exist)">Rick Ross</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juicy_J" title="Juicy J">Juicy J</a>, and T.I. was later distributed.<sup id="cite_ref-MTV_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MTV-118">[118]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Right_Now_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Right Now (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Right Now</a>" featuring David Guetta serves as the fourth single from the album and peaked at number fifty on the Hot 100.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard.com_117-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard.com-117">[117]</a></sup> As promotion prior to the album's release, Rihanna embarked on the 777 Tour, a mini tour of seven shows in seven countries in seven days.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rihanna_777_Documentary..._7Countries7Days7Shows&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rihanna 777 Documentary... 7Countries7Days7Shows (page does not exist)">documentary DVD</a> of the tour was later released.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna_Singapore_08.jpg" title="File:Rihanna Singapore 08.jpg">File:Rihanna Singapore 08.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing during the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamonds_World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamonds World Tour (page does not exist)">Diamonds World Tour</a>" in 2013</div></div></div>
<p>In February 2013 at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=55th_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="55th Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">55th Grammy Awards</a>, Rihanna won her sixth Grammy Award, in the category <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_for_Best_Short_Form_Music_Video&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award for Best Short Form Music Video (page does not exist)">Best Short Form Music Video</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love_(music_video)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (music video) (page does not exist)">We Found Love</a>" (2011).<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Also that month, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Official_Charts_Company&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Official Charts Company (page does not exist)">Official Charts Company</a> announced that Rihanna had sold 3,868,000 records in the past year in the UK alone, ranking at number one in the list of <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_BRIT_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 BRIT Awards (page does not exist)">2013 BRIT Awards</a> artist nominees.<sup id="cite_ref-officialcharts.com_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-officialcharts.com-113">[113]</a></sup> Rihanna's fifth headlining concert tour, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamonds_World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamonds World Tour (page does not exist)">Diamonds World Tour</a>, began in March 2013 in support of <i>Unapologetic</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup>  Rihanna appeared in the <a href="/wiki/Seth_Rogen" title="Seth Rogen">Seth Rogen</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evan_Goldberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evan Goldberg (page does not exist)">Evan Goldberg</a> comedy film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=This_Is_the_End&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="This Is the End (page does not exist)">This Is the End</a></i>, released in June 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> That same month, American hip hop artist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wale_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wale (rapper) (page does not exist)">Wale</a> released a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bad_(Wale_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bad (Wale song) (page does not exist)">remixed version</a> of his single "Bad" featuring Rihanna.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> In October 2013, Eminem released his Rihanna-assisted single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Monster_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Monster (song) (page does not exist)">The Monster</a>", the fourth release off his eighth studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Marshall_Mathers_LP_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Marshall Mathers LP 2 (page does not exist)">The Marshall Mathers LP 2</a></i>. With the song entering the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UK_Singles_Chart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UK Singles Chart (page does not exist)">UK Singles Chart</a> at number one, Rihanna joins <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> as just one of three acts to have scored a number one single each year over seven consecutive years in the chart's history.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> The song peaked at number one on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a>, which marked Rihanna's 13th US number one, tying her with Michael Jackson for the third most number ones in the chart's 55 year history. Additionally, Rihanna became the fastest solo artist to achieve 13 chart-toppers, surpassing the previous record held by Mariah Carey (seven-years, eight-month and 19 days), with only <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> reaching 13 number ones more quickly.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2014.E2.80.93present:_Eighth_studio_album">2014–present: Eighth studio album</span></h3>
<p>In December 2013, rapper <a href="/wiki/Pitbull_(rapper)" title="Pitbull (rapper)">Pitbull</a> revealed during an interview that the featured artist on his song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Timber_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Timber (song) (page does not exist)">Timber</a>" was originally supposed to be Rihanna. However, he stated that she was already asked to be the featured artist on the lead single from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shakira&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shakira (page does not exist)">Shakira</a>'s upcoming album and did not have time to record the track.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Can%27t_Remember_to_Forget_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Can't Remember to Forget You (page does not exist)">Can't Remember to Forget You</a>", the lead single from Shakira's upcoming album, was released on January 13, 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2014, it was announced that Rihanna had started planning her eighth studio album. Rihanna is working with producers including <a href="/w/index.php?title=DJ_Mustard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DJ Mustard (page does not exist)">DJ Mustard</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Guetta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Guetta (page does not exist)">David Guetta</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicky_Romero&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicky Romero (page does not exist)">Nicky Romero</a> for the project.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Artistry">Artistry</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_voice">Music and voice</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
While recording tracks for her third studio album, <i>Good Girl Gone Bad</i>, Rihanna took vocal lessons from Ne-Yo. Speaking of the experience she stated, "I've never had vocal training, so when I'm in the studio, he'll tell me how to breathe and stuff... He'll call out these big fancy words: 'OK, I want you to do <a href="/wiki/Staccato" title="Staccato">staccato</a>.' And I'm like, 'OK, I don't know what that is.'"<sup id="cite_ref-VoiceLessons_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VoiceLessons-37">[37]</a></sup> Her vocal performance on <i>Loud</i> (2010) received positive reviews from music critics. James Skinner from <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a> praised Rihanna's vocals on the song "Love the Way You Lie (Part II)" and wrote that her voice is powerful and that "it is Rihanna’s vocal – at once commanding, soulful and vulnerable – that anchors the song, and Loud itself".<sup id="cite_ref-BBCLoudReview_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCLoudReview-131">[131]</a></sup> Andy Gill from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Independent" title="The Independent">The Independent</a></i> feels that "California King Bed" features her best vocal performance.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> In a review of <i>Unapologetic</i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> magazine wrote, "Diamonds" "finds Rihanna doing one of her throatiest, most impassioned vocals to date, on this inspirational pop ballad."<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Jon Caramanica of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> stated, "over the years, as her game face froze in place, her voice cured into a weapon of emotional chill and strategic indifference. It’s decidedly unfriendly, made to give orders".<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> Volume 65 of the <i>Contemporary Black Biography</i> book series notes that "Rihanna is the rare rhythm and blues diva to emerge from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a> world."<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RihannaLastGirlOnEarthSnapMar2011.jpg" title="File:RihannaLastGirlOnEarthSnapMar2011.jpg">File:RihannaLastGirlOnEarthSnapMar2011.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing on her <a href="/w/index.php?title=Last_Girl_on_Earth_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Last Girl on Earth Tour (page does not exist)">Last Girl on Earth Tour</a> in March 2011</div></div></div>
<p>At the time of her debut, she was marketed as a <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a> singer because of her Caribbean descent.<sup id="cite_ref-AllmusicMusicSun_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AllmusicMusicSun-136">[136]</a></sup> She began recording songs that were inspired by caribbean music genres such as <a href="/wiki/Soca_music" title="Soca music">soca</a>, dancehall, and reggae. She later departed into a broad range of musical genres such as dance-pop, hip hop, dubstep, rock, and house.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Some of her songs are also inspired through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sampling_(music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sampling (music) (page does not exist)">samples</a>, containing samples from other artists.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> The combination of dancehall and reggae genres on her debut album, <i>Music of the Sun</i> (2005), was complemented by Kelefa Sanneh of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, who said, "Dancehall reggae sometimes seems like a furiously insular form of music, but ... Rihanna is only the latest singer to discover how versatile the genre's spring-loaded electronic rhythms can be".<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Her debut album featured production from Stargate and production duo <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carl_Sturken_and_Evan_Rogers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carl Sturken and Evan Rogers (page does not exist)">Carl Sturken and Evan Rogers</a>, who discovered her and helped launch her career with her debut single "Pon de Replay".<sup id="cite_ref-VoiceLessons_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VoiceLessons-37">[37]</a></sup> <i>A Girl Like Me</i> (2006) saw Rihanna infuse a bit of rock music on the track "Kisses Don't Lie",<sup id="cite_ref-RockSideLP_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RockSideLP-140">[140]</a></sup> a sound she would also use on tracks like "Shut Up and Drive" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rockstar_101&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rockstar 101 (page does not exist)">Rockstar 101</a>". The album included pop and R&amp;B. Rihanna worked again with Sturken and Rogers, J.R. Rotem, and label-mate <a href="/wiki/Ne-Yo" title="Ne-Yo">Ne-Yo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SOSsampled_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SOSsampled-141">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The ballads on the album were described as elegant and mature, showing artistic growth.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>With <i>Good Girl Gone Bad</i> (2007), she took a different direction from the dancehall influence of her previous efforts with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uptempo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uptempo (page does not exist)">uptempo</a> songs.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> "[At] this stage I feel like I want to do a lot of uptempo [songs] ... but still be soulful at the same time", she said.<sup id="cite_ref-VoiceLessons_37-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VoiceLessons-37">[37]</a></sup> She worked with new producers on the album, including Timbaland, Sean Garrett, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christopher_%22Tricky%22_Stewart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christopher &quot;Tricky&quot; Stewart (page does not exist)">Christopher "Tricky" Stewart</a>, who produced the international hit "Umbrella", a major breakthrough.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Rihanna again entered a new musical and lyrical direction with <i>Rated R</i>, departing from her previous up-tempo and dance-pop style with elements of hip hop, rock, dubstep, and dancehall.<sup id="cite_ref-VentedOnLP_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VentedOnLP-146">[146]</a></sup> Recorded after the assault by her then-boyfriend, Chris Brown, the album had a much darker tone and was filled with various emotions she experienced throughout 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-VentedOnLP_146-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VentedOnLP-146">[146]</a></sup> She continued to reinvent her music and sound with <i>Loud</i> (2010). She wanted to have more fun with her music and image while experimenting with new material. "With <i>Loud</i>, I got a bit more rebellious and did whatever I wanted to do. I reinvented my image and took creative control", she said.<sup id="cite_ref-biggest_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biggest-147">[147]</a></sup> Unlike <i>Rated R</i>,  <i>Loud</i> reflects the sassy, fun, flirty, and energetic attitude she had while recording the album.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> The album is a mixture of ballads, party anthems, and empowering love songs with elements of up-tempo and pop genres, ranging from dance-pop to R&amp;B.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Described as "a sexy, sexual record", <i>Talk That Talk</i> (2011) was similar to <i>Rated R</i>, as both contain hip hop, R&amp;B, dancehall, and dubstep genres.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> <i>Loud</i> and <i>Talk That Talk</i> also saw her return to her dancehall roots, evident in the tracks like "Man Down" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Watch_n%27_Learn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Watch n' Learn (page does not exist)">Watch n' Learn</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> She also branched out into house music with tracks like "We Found Love", "Only Girl (In the World)" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Complicated_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complicated (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Complicated</a>."<sup id="cite_ref-NewMadonna_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewMadonna-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<p>Rihanna has named <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a> as her idol and biggest influence. She said she wants to be the "black Madonna".<sup id="cite_ref-biggest_147-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biggest-147">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> "I think that Madonna was a great inspiration for me, especially on my earlier work. If I had to examine her evolution through time, I think she reinvented her clothing style and music with success every single time. And at the same time remained a real force in entertainment in the whole world."<sup id="cite_ref-biggest_147-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biggest-147">[147]</a></sup> She also cites <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">Whitney Houston</a> as a major influence and idol,<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mariah_Carey" title="Mariah Carey">Mariah Carey</a><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a><sup id="cite_ref-RihUpstaged_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RihUpstaged-156">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BringsRiddims_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BringsRiddims-157">[157]</a></sup> as major influences.
