Of <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">Janet Jackson</a>, Rihanna has commented that "[s]he was one of the first female pop icons that I could relate to."<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Rihanna has said the late R&amp;B singer <a href="/wiki/Aaliyah" title="Aaliyah">Aaliyah</a> has a huge impact on her style and also complimented on the singers artistry as well.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> Rihanna was inspired to start her career after watching Beyoncé on television with <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna commented that <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vintage_clothing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vintage clothing (page does not exist)">vintage clothing</a> served as visual inspiration for the music video "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hate_That_I_Love_You&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hate That I Love You (page does not exist)">Hate That I Love You</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rehab_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rehab (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Rehab</a>". The "dark, creepy" scenes of "Disturbia" have been compared to Michael Jackson's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Jackson%27s_Thriller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Jackson's Thriller (page does not exist)">Thriller</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-star_tribune_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star_tribune-161">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> Other musical influences include <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Keys" title="Alicia Keys">Alicia Keys</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Sixshot_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sixshot-163">[163]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fefe_Dobson" title="Fefe Dobson">Fefe Dobson</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-kidzworld_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kidzworld-164">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Celine_Dion" title="Celine Dion">Celine Dion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-artistdirect_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-artistdirect-166">[166]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brandy_Norwood" title="Brandy Norwood">Brandy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Gwen_Stefani" title="Gwen Stefani">Gwen Stefani</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> Jon Bream of the <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Tribune" title="Star Tribune">Star Tribune</a></i> commented "[i]n the tradition of Madonna and Janet Jackson, Rihanna has become the video vixen of the '00s&#160;... Rihanna has perfected the pout, the long-legged strut and trend-setting hairdos that keep women and men alike checking her out on YouTube."<sup id="cite_ref-star_tribune_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-star_tribune-161">[161]</a></sup> George Epaminondas of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=InStyle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="InStyle (page does not exist)">InStyle</a></i> considers Rihanna's music videos to be "cinematic" due to her "blend of lush island rhythms and swinging pop and&#160;... mischievous sensuality."<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna's music contains strong influences of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caribbean_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caribbean music (page does not exist)">Caribbean music</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Reggae" title="Reggae">reggae</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dancehall" title="Dancehall">dancehall</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RudeBoyArt_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RudeBoyArt-170">[170]</a></sup> The video for "Rude Boy" was inspired by her Caribbean roots.<sup id="cite_ref-RudeBoyArt_170-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RudeBoyArt-170">[170]</a></sup> She stated that while growing up in <a href="/wiki/Barbados" title="Barbados">Barbados</a> she listened to reggae music, and when she came to the United States she was exposed to many different types of music.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> Rihanna is heavily influenced by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jamaican&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jamaican (page does not exist)">Jamaican</a> singer-songwriter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Marley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Marley (page does not exist)">Bob Marley</a>. She stated, "[h]e's one of my favorite artists of all time [...] he really paved the way for every other artist out of the Caribbean".<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> She built a <a href="/wiki/Shrine" title="Shrine">shrine</a> in her home dedicated to Marley.<sup id="cite_ref-MarleyTribute_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarleyTribute-173">[173]</a></sup> Rihanna has covered Marley's "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Is_This_Love_(Bob_Marley_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Is This Love (Bob Marley song) (page does not exist)">Is This Love</a>" and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Marley_%26_The_Wailers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Marley &amp; The Wailers (page does not exist)">Bob Marley &amp; The Wailers</a>' "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Redemption_Song_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Redemption Song (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Redemption Song</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Videos_and_stage">Videos and stage</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna_with_dancers_live_at_Kollen_Music_Festival_2012.jpg" title="File:Rihanna with dancers live at Kollen Music Festival 2012.jpg">File:Rihanna with dancers live at Kollen Music Festival 2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing at Kollen Music Festival, June 2012</div></div></div>
<p>Rihanna has worked with music video director <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthony_Mandler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthony Mandler (page does not exist)">Anthony Mandler</a> on more than a dozen <a href="/wiki/Music_videos" title="Music videos" class="mw-redirect">music videos</a>, the first being "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Unfaithful_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unfaithful (song) (page does not exist)">Unfaithful</a>" (2006).<sup id="cite_ref-ManDownVid_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ManDownVid-175">[175]</a></sup> "We've done 16 videos together; they're not all tough, [...] Yeah, I mean, I'm known for the 'Disturbia's and the 'Russian Roulette's and things like that, but 'Only Girl (In the World)' is certainly an ethereal kind of empowering, beauty-filled video," Mandler said.<sup id="cite_ref-ManDownVid_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ManDownVid-175">[175]</a></sup> Jocelyn Vena of MTV wrote, "Rihanna, like Madonna, also has a tendency to make truly thought-provoking music videos that fit the songs they represent. Smattered in between glitzier, more glamorous clips, Madge and Ri want us to think about bigger issues".<sup id="cite_ref-NewMadonna_152-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewMadonna-152">[152]</a></sup> "Unfaithful", "Love The Way You Lie", "Man Down", and "We Found Love" were shot as short films exploring issues such as love triangles, abuse, and substance abuse romance.<sup id="cite_ref-NewMadonna_152-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewMadonna-152">[152]</a></sup> Her music video for "Umbrella" shows Rihanna's transition into adulthood and her newly adopted image.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Tamar Anitai from MTV Buzzworthy listed "Disturbia" at number five on the "Buzzworthy's Top 5 Most Paranoid Music Videos". He said that "Paranoia never looked so supernaturally sexy!".<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> The video for "Russian Roulette" features Rihanna in a padded room playing a game of <a href="/wiki/Russian_roulette" title="Russian roulette">russian roulette</a> with her partner. A  scene of Rihanna being approached by a speeding car at night was compared to the altercation with Chris Brown.<sup id="cite_ref-Top5MostVids_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top5MostVids-178">[178]</a></sup> The Caribbean-inspired music video for "Rude Boy" was compared to rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=M.I.A._(artist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="M.I.A. (artist) (page does not exist)">M.I.A.</a>'s video "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Boyz_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boyz (song) (page does not exist)">Boyz</a>" by many critics for its colorful aesthetic similarities.<sup id="cite_ref-RudeBoyArt_170-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RudeBoyArt-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, Rihanna released three controversial music videos about sadomasochism, rape, and domestic violence. The video for "S&amp;M" was banned in eleven countries for its sexual content.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> "Man Down", which features Rihanna shooting a man in a train station, was criticized by the <a href="/wiki/Parents_Television_Council" title="Parents Television Council">Parents Television Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> "We Found Love", which shows Rihanna and her love interest in a drug-filled unhealthy relationship,<sup id="cite_ref-Top5MostVids_178-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top5MostVids-178">[178]</a></sup> sparked criticism from the Rape Crisis Centre for its inappropriate message.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Charne Graham of the <i><a href="/wiki/Houston_Press" title="Houston Press">Houston Press</a></i> stated, "Why should Rihanna's music videos get everyone riled up when others' equally sexual and controversial videos are in rotation?" He added, "she just like to make music videos that give us something to talk about".<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Rihanna is the first woman to pass two billion cumulative views on the music video website <a href="/w/index.php?title=VEVO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="VEVO (page does not exist)">VEVO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> As of September 2013, she has accumulated over four billion views on the site.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>Denis Armstrong of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canadian_Online_Explorer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canadian Online Explorer (page does not exist)">Canadian Online Explorer</a> commented on her performance at the <a href="/wiki/Ottawa_Bluesfest" title="Ottawa Bluesfest">Ottawa Bluesfest</a>, saying "her show was a Disney-esque choreographed fantasy of non-stop hip-swiveling, sassy attitude and personal endearments and a string of funky, sugar-free hits."<sup id="cite_ref-JamCanoe_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JamCanoe-185">[185]</a></sup> Her performance of "Disturbia" at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_MTV_Video_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 MTV Video Music Awards (page does not exist)">2008 MTV Video Music Awards</a> was ranked tenth best on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=MTV_Video_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTV Video Music Awards (page does not exist)">MTV Video Music Awards</a>, according to a <i>Billboard</i> poll.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> Her revealing leather costumes during her Good Girl Gone Bad Tour were highly criticized by Malaysia's conservative Islamic party, who recommended that her concert tour should be banned.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> Whilst commenting on her third album's accompanying tour, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i> compared Rihanna's stage wardrobe styling to that of Janet Jackson and called her "a vision of <a href="/wiki/Ann_Summers" title="Ann Summers">Ann Summers</a> couture in thigh-high boots and a few scraps of black PVC."<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> In the October 2011 issue of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Vogue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Vogue (page does not exist)">British Vogue</a></i>, Rihanna said her performance outfits and appearances are all an act; "[t]hat’s not me. That’s a part I play. You know, like it’s a piece of art, with all these toys and textures to play with".<sup id="cite_ref-RoleModel_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RoleModel-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_image">Public image</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna_AMA_2009_Red_carpet.jpg" title="File:Rihanna AMA 2009 Red carpet.jpg">File:Rihanna AMA 2009 Red carpet.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Music Awards (page does not exist)">American Music Awards</a> red carpet, November 2009</div></div></div>
<p>In 2009, <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_(magazine)" title="New York (magazine)">New York</a></i> magazine described Rihanna's early look as that of a cookie-cutter teen queen, noting she has the ability to shift looks dramatically and with great ease.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Around the time of the release of her second studio album, <i>A Girl Like Me</i> (2006), many critics felt that Rihanna's style, sound, and musical material were too similar to those of Beyoncé.<sup id="cite_ref-Washingtonpost_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Washingtonpost-191">[191]</a></sup> Negative reviews appeared in which her music,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> music videos, performances<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> and her image were unfavorably compared to those of Beyoncé.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Some media even claimed that Jay-Z fashioned her to be a replica of Beyoncé.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> Rihanna went told <i>Look</i> magazine that "Beyoncé is a great artist and I feel honored to be mentioned in the same sentence, but we're different performers with different styles".<sup id="cite_ref-MyLeague_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MyLeague-197">[197]</a></sup> The accompanying music video for "Umbrella" introduced Rihanna's new image, with her hair chopped off and dyed jet black, which was inspired by <a href="/wiki/Charlize_Theron" title="Charlize Theron">Charlize Theron</a>'s bob cut in the science fiction thriller <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=%C3%86on_Flux_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Æon Flux (film) (page does not exist)">Æon Flux</a></i> (2005).<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> In an article for <a href="/wiki/MTV_News" title="MTV News">MTV News</a>, Rob Markmanm wrote, "Her 2007 album <i>Good Girl Gone Bad</i> seemed to serve as a precursor for what was to come. No longer a spotless, pop starlet who plays by the rules, Rihanna has emerged as a fiery heroine to rebellious girls everywhere."<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Known for reinventing her style and image, she has changed her personal appearance several times, scoring different hairstyles since the release of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad (page does not exist)">her third album</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hebert_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hebert-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rihanna.27s_hairstyles_in_pictures_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rihanna.27s_hairstyles_in_pictures-3">[3]</a></sup> When putting together her own wardrobe she stated, "It's become more about taking a risk [...] I always look for the most interesting silhouette or something that's a little off."<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> Jess Cartner-Morley of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Guardian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Guardian (page does not exist)">The Guardian</a></i> wrote that "Rihanna's wardrobe is the most talked-about, influential and dissected in pop right now" and that whatever she wears "is immediately reproduced on the high street, because it sells".<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> However, her style evolution has been criticized by many critics for it's strong message and revealing outfits.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/People_(magazine)" title="People (magazine)">People</a></i> listed her second on its "10 Best Dressed Stars of 2008" list, writing: "Rihanna hit all the right notes in her sophisticated mix of glamorous gowns."<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> Country singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miranda_Lambert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miranda Lambert (page does not exist)">Miranda Lambert</a> admires Rihanna's fashion and style. "I don’t necessarily get inspired by the whole no-bra thing, but I love that you never know what she’s going to wear. It always keeps you guessing, which makes her sassy and interesting."<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> Commenting on the cultural expectation for pop stars to be <a href="/wiki/Role_model" title="Role model">role models</a>, she said "[being a role model] became more of my job than I wanted it to be. But no, I just want to make music. That's it".<sup id="cite_ref-RoleModel_189-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RoleModel-189">[189]</a></sup> In a May 2013 interview with MTV, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Vagina_Monologues" title="The Vagina Monologues">The Vagina Monologues</a></i> writer and feminist <a href="/wiki/Eve_Ensler" title="Eve Ensler">Eve Ensler</a> praised the singer, saying, "I'm a huge Rihanna fan, I think she has a kind of agency over her sexuality and she's open about her sexuality, she has enormous grace and she's immensely talented."<sup id="cite_ref-PraisedVagina_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PraisedVagina-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna,_LOUD_Tour,_Florida_6.jpg" title="File:Rihanna, LOUD Tour, Florida 6.jpg">File:Rihanna, LOUD Tour, Florida 6.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna on her tour <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Loud_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Loud Tour (page does not exist)">The Loud Tour</a> in July 2011</div></div></div>
<p>Despite being recognized for her sex appeal, she revealed being a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sex_symbol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sex symbol (page does not exist)">sex symbol</a> is not a priority and that "it’s definitely flattering, but also uncomfortable."<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> Emily Hewett from <i><a href="/wiki/Metro_(British_newspaper)" title="Metro (British newspaper)">Metro</a></i> wrote, "Rihanna is quite possibly THE most sexiest woman in the world. The 25-year-old songbird can grind like no other, pull off a provocative pose better than a Playboy pro [...] Rihanna looks good in anything. Yes, ANYTHING. She even managed to make boiler suits look sexy in <i>Battleship</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Her appearance has landed her on the cover of magazines such as <i><a href="/wiki/Maxim_(magazine)" title="Maxim (magazine)">Maxim</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/FHM" title="FHM">FHM</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/GQ" title="GQ">GQ</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-BET20Covers_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BET20Covers-208">[208]</a></sup> She has appeared in the top ten on <i>Maxim</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> Hot 100 list and on <i>FHM</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> "100 Sexiest Women in the World" several times.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> She was named the Venus Breeze's Celebrity Legs of a Goddess by <a href="/wiki/Gillette_(brand)" title="Gillette (brand)">Gillette</a> in 2007 and Diva of the year by <i><a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">Entertainment Weekly</a></i> in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> In 2009, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Glamour_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glamour (magazine) (page does not exist)">Glamour</a></i> ranked her at number 17 on the 50 Most Glamorous Women and <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i> named her the Sexiest Woman Alive of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> In December 2012, Rihanna became the first woman to be featured on the cover of <i>GQ</i> magazine’s "Men of the Year" issue and ranked fifth on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Complex_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complex (magazine) (page does not exist)">Complex</a></i> list of "100 Hottest Female Singers of All Time".<sup id="cite_ref-BET20Covers_208-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BET20Covers-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ComplexSingers_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ComplexSingers-215">[215]</a></sup> The following year, <a href="/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a> placed Rihanna second on their list of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Greatest_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Greatest (TV series) (page does not exist)">100 Sexiest Artists</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup>
</p><p>She has a collection of small tattoos: a music note on her ankle, a pisces sign behind her right ear, a Sanskrit prayer on her hip, a star in her left ear, the word "Love" on her left middle finger, the phrase "Freedom in Messiah" in Arabic on her ribcage, a trail of stars going down the back of her neck, a skull with a pink hair bow on the back of her foot, the word "Shhh..." on her right index finger, the date 4.11.1986 in <a href="/wiki/Roman_numerals" title="Roman numerals">roman numerals</a> on top of her left shoulder, a henna-style dragon claw on her hand, a handgun on her ribcage, the motto "never a failure, always a lesson" near her right shoulder, a rebelle fleur on her neck, the words "Thug Life" on her knuckles, a small cross on her collar bone, an Egyptian falcon shaped like a gun on her right foot, and a <a href="/wiki/Isis" title="Isis">goddess Isis</a> above her stomach.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Rihanna's first albums established her as a "Pop/R&amp;B Princess"<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Music_journalism" title="Music journalism">music critics</a>; Nick Levine of <a href="/wiki/Digital_Spy" title="Digital Spy">Digital Spy</a> described her third studio album <i>Good Girl Gone Bad: Reloaded</i>, as the closest thing to a <i><a href="/wiki/Thriller_(Michael_Jackson_album)" title="Thriller (Michael Jackson album)">Thriller</a></i> that 2007/8 is likely to produce.<sup id="cite_ref-digital_spy_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-digital_spy-220">[220]</a></sup> Her single "Umbrella", famous for its "ella ella" hook, is considered by <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> to be one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="500 Greatest Songs of All Time (page does not exist)">500 greatest songs of all time</a> and received critical acclaim.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> Her 2011 single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (page does not exist)">We Found Love</a>" was ranked by <i>Billboard</i> as the 24th biggest US <i>Billboard </i>Hot 100 hit of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-1">[1]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Found_Love_(music_video)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Found Love (music video) (page does not exist)">music video</a> for the song was also received with acclaim, winning the Grammy for <a href="/wiki/Best_Short_Form_Music_Video" title="Best Short Form Music Video" class="mw-redirect">Best Short Form Music Video</a> and MTV's <a href="/wiki/MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Video_of_the_Year" title="MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year">Video of the Year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nominees_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nominees-223">[223]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time Magazine</a></i> included Rihanna on its 100 Most Influential People in 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> with fashion designer <a href="/wiki/Stella_McCartney" title="Stella McCartney">Stella McCartney</a> writing, "She's one of the coolest, hottest, most talented, most liked, most listened to, most followed, most impressive artists at work today, but she does it in her own stride. She works hard, very hard."<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> The following month, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes (magazine) (page does not exist)">Forbes</a></i> ranked Rihanna fourth on their Most Powerful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_Celebrity_100&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes Celebrity 100 (page does not exist)">Celebrity 100</a> list, with earnings of $53 million between May 2011 and May 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-226">[226]</a></sup> In November 2013, Rihanna was given the "Icon Award" at the 2013 American Music Awards, with the show's producer, Larry Klein commenting: "The first-ever Icon Award was created to honor an artist whose body of work has made a profound influence over pop music on a global level [...] Rihanna’s iconic and innovative sound has enabled her to become one of the most influential and best-selling artists of all time."<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna_live_at_Kollen_Music_Festival_2012_cropped.jpg" title="File:Rihanna live at Kollen Music Festival 2012 cropped.jpg">File:Rihanna live at Kollen Music Festival 2012 cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing at Kollen Music Festival 2012</div></div></div>
<p>Rihanna has sold over 30 million albums and 120 million singles worldwide,<sup id="cite_ref-sales_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sales-229">[229]</a></sup> making her one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music artists</a> of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-Worldwide_sales_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Worldwide_sales-4">[4]</a></sup> In the United States, Rihanna has sold over 10 million albums,<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Nielsen_SoundScan" title="Nielsen SoundScan">Nielsen SoundScan</a> ranked her as the best-selling digital artist in the country, breaking a <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Record</a> for digital single sales of over 58 million as of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard_cover_story_2012_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard_cover_story_2012-231">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DigitalSales_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DigitalSales-232">[232]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> She has released six <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA) <a href="/wiki/RIAA_certification" title="RIAA certification">certified</a> platinum and multi-platinum albums in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> Her collaboration with Eminem, "Love the Way You Lie", together with "Umbrella", "Disturbia", "Only Girl (In the World)", "We Found Love", and "Diamonds", are some of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-selling_singles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-selling singles (page does not exist)">best-selling singles</a> of all time worldwide. The singer has accumulated thirteen number one singles on the US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 chart, tying with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Jackson (page does not exist)">Michael Jackson</a> for the third most number ones in chart's history.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> She has been named the top <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pop_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pop Songs (page does not exist)">Pop Songs</a> chart artist of the past twenty years by <i>Billboard</i>; she ranks first with most entries (36), most top tens (23), and most number ones (10).<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> In 2012, Rihanna became the third most-played <a href="/wiki/Top_40_(radio_format)" title="Top 40 (radio format)" class="mw-redirect">Top 40</a> artist based on <a href="/wiki/Mediabase" title="Mediabase">Mediabase</a> of <a href="/wiki/Clear_Channel_Communications" title="Clear Channel Communications">Clear Channel Communications</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> As of June 2012, Rihanna has sold over 14 million singles and six million albums in the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-UKRecordSales_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKRecordSales-238">[238]</a></sup> She is the tenth best-selling<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> and the second best-selling female singles artist in the country, only behind Madonna.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> In August 2013, Rihanna was named the 15th biggest US <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 artist of all time,<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> becoming the highest ranking newcomer on the list since the last time <i>Billboard</i> compiled all time artists in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> In the same month, <i>Billboard</i> ranked Rihanna the top Hot 100 artist of the 2010s decade.<sup id="cite_ref-Hot1002010s_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hot1002010s-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rihanna's work has directly influenced a number of contemporary artists such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Little_Mix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Little Mix (page does not exist)">Little Mix</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Selena_Gomez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Selena Gomez (page does not exist)">Selena Gomez</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Justin_Bieber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Justin Bieber (page does not exist)">Justin Bieber</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellie_Goulding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ellie Goulding (page does not exist)">Ellie Goulding</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Demi_Lovato&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Demi Lovato (page does not exist)">Demi Lovato</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Demi_Lovato_influence_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Demi_Lovato_influence-247">[247]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Willow_Smith" title="Willow Smith">Willow Smith</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard16_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard16-248">[248]</a></sup> Rihanna has an honorary title of Ambassador for Culture and Youth in Barbados.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> Additionally, Rihanna has become a dominating figure in social media and internet streaming, ranking at number one on <i>Forbes</i>' list of Social Networking Superstars.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> She is the most popular person on the social network <a href="/w/index.php?title=Facebook&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Facebook (page does not exist)">Facebook</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> has the sixth most followers on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twitter (page does not exist)">Twitter</a>, and is the most-viewed and subscribed recording artist on <a href="/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="YouTube (page does not exist)">YouTube</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup> On March 7, 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spotify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spotify (page does not exist)">Spotify</a> announced that Rihanna is the most streamed artist worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> In 2013, Rihanna was also named the most influential artist in the United Kingdom and the most influential celebrity on the internet.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_ventures">Other ventures</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Endorsements">Endorsements</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dominique_Young_Unique_and_Rihanna.jpg" title="File:Dominique Young Unique and Rihanna.jpg">File:Dominique Young Unique and Rihanna.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna with rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominique_Young_Unique&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominique Young Unique (page does not exist)">Dominique Young Unique</a> at her River Island fashion launch in 2013.</div></div></div>
<p>Rihanna has ventured into other businesses and industries. In October 2005, Rihanna struck an endorsement deal (her first of many) with Secret Body Spray.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> In 2010 Rihanna featured in the <a href="/wiki/Optus" title="Optus">Optus</a> commercial, in conjunction with Optus supporting Rihanna's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Last_Girl_on_Earth_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Last Girl on Earth Tour (page does not exist)">Last Girl on Earth Tour</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-optus_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-optus-257">[257]</a></sup> The same year Rihanna also featured in the <a href="/wiki/Eastman_Kodak" title="Eastman Kodak">Kodak</a> commercial along with rapper Pitbull.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup>
In October 2010, the singer released an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rihanna_(book)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rihanna (book) (page does not exist)">eponymous book</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> The book, featured photos from Rihanna's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Last_Girl_on_Earth_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Last Girl on Earth Tour (page does not exist)">Last Girl on Earth Tour</a></i> and served as an accompaniment to her fourth studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rated_R_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rated R (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Rated R</a></i> (2009).
</p><p>Rihanna's first fragrance, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Reb%27l_Fleur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reb'l Fleur (page does not exist)">Reb'l Fleur</a>", was released on January 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-cocoperez1_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cocoperez1-260">[260]</a></sup> The product became highly successful, according to <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i>, Reb'l Fleur was a financial success and was expected to gross US$80 million at retail by the end of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-RS_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RS-261">[261]</a></sup>
In 2011 <a href="/wiki/Nivea" title="Nivea">Nivea</a> celebrated its "100 Years of Skincare" festivities which featured several performances from Rihanna.<sup id="cite_ref-popcrush1_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popcrush1-262">[262]</a></sup> Rihanna's song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=California_King_Bed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California King Bed (page does not exist)">California King Bed</a>" was featured as a part of the "100 Years of Skincare" commercial campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-rihannanow1_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rihannanow1-263">[263]</a></sup> Rihanna also became the face of Vita Coco in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup>
Rihanna's second fragrance, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rebelle_(fragrance)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rebelle (fragrance) (page does not exist)">Rebelle</a>", was released in February 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> The promotional campaign for Rebelle, was shot by director, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anthony_Mandler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anthony Mandler (page does not exist)">Anthony Mandler</a>, who also shot the promotional campaign for Reb'l Fleur.<sup id="cite_ref-billboard_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billboard-266">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2012, Rihanna released her third fragrance, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Nude_by_Rihanna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nude by Rihanna (page does not exist)">Nude</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-Nude_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nude-267">[267]</a></sup> In 2013, the singer collaborated with <a href="/w/index.php?title=MAC_Cosmetics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MAC Cosmetics (page does not exist)">MAC Cosmetics</a> and released her own summer, fall and holiday lines of makeup called "RiRi hearts MAC".<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> In July 2013, <a href="/wiki/Pale_lager" title="Pale lager">lager</a> production company <a href="/wiki/Budweiser_(Anheuser-Busch)" title="Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)">Budweiser</a> announced that Rihanna had become a part of their global "Made For Music" campaign, also co-starring <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>. A commercial video was released featuring the singer and song "Right Now".<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup>
Rihanna's fourth women's fragrance, titled "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rogue_by_Rihanna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rogue by Rihanna (page does not exist)">Rogue</a>" was released on September 14, 2013. The singer announces to release a men's version the following year.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> In December 2013, it was announced Rihanna would become the face of French fashion range <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balmain_(fashion_house)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balmain (fashion house) (page does not exist)">Balmain</a> during the spring/summer 2014 collection.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion">Fashion</span></h3>
<p>The singer's first fashion range, for <a href="/wiki/Armani" title="Armani">Armani</a>, became available in November 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-armani_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-armani-272">[272]</a></sup> Rihanna's 2010 song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Skin_(Rihanna_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skin (Rihanna song) (page does not exist)">Skin</a>" was used in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Armani_Jeans_(brand)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Armani Jeans (brand) (page does not exist)">Armani Jeans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emporio_Armani" title="Emporio Armani" class="mw-redirect">Emporio Armani Underwear</a> adds.<sup id="cite_ref-brand_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brand-273">[273]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup>
Her first television program, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Styled_to_Rock_(UK_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Styled to Rock (UK TV series) (page does not exist)">Styled to Rock</a></i>, premiered in the UK in August 2012 on <a href="/wiki/Sky_Living" title="Sky Living">Sky Living</a>. In the ten-week series, Rihanna, <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Roberts" title="Nicola Roberts">Nicola Roberts</a>, Lysa Cooper, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henry_Holland_(fashion_designer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henry Holland (fashion designer) (page does not exist)">Henry Holland</a> assist up-and-coming British designers with their clothing lines.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup>
In February 2013, Rihanna presented her first women's spring fashion collection at <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_Fashion_Week&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London Fashion Week (page does not exist)">London Fashion Week</a> for British street fashion brand <a href="/wiki/River_Island" title="River Island">River Island</a>, collaborating with her personal stylist Adam Selman.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup> They published two more collections for the brand, a summer edition released on May 25, 2013 and an autumn edition released on September 10, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> The fourth and last collection for River Island, the winter edition was released on November 7, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup>
Meanwhile, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Styled_to_Rock_(U.S._TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Styled to Rock (U.S. TV series) (page does not exist)">US version of <i>Styled to Rock</i></a> premiered on October 25, 2013 on <a href="/wiki/Bravo_(U.S._TV_channel)" title="Bravo (U.S. TV channel)">Bravo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> In December 2013, it was announced that Rihanna is set to be the new face of the forthcoming spring/summer 2014 campaign - due to appear in magazines from January - of the French fashion house <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balmain_(fashion_house)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balmain (fashion house) (page does not exist)">Balmain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy">Philanthropy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rihanna_-_We_Found_Love_-_Birmingham_Loud_Tour.jpg" title="File:Rihanna - We Found Love - Birmingham Loud Tour.jpg">File:Rihanna - We Found Love - Birmingham Loud Tour.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Rihanna performing "We Found Love" in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birmingham&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birmingham (page does not exist)">Birmingham</a> during her Loud Tour</div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, she created her Believe Foundation to help terminally ill children.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup>
In 2007, Rihanna was named as one of the Cartier Love Charity Bracelet Ambassadors, with each celebrity representing a different global charity.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup>
To help raise awareness and combat <a href="/w/index.php?title=HIV/AIDS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HIV/AIDS (page does not exist)">HIV/AIDS</a>, Rihanna and other public figures designed clothing for the February 2008 <a href="/wiki/H%26M" title="H&amp;M">H&amp;M</a> Fashion Against AIDS line.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup>
In 2008, Rihanna performed a series of charity concerts entitled <a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Girl%27s_Night_Out&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Girl's Night Out (page does not exist)">A Girl's Night Out</a><sup id="cite_ref-people_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-people-286">[286]</a></sup> to benefit the "Believe Foundation". The concerts were made free for the public. Money from sponsors and advertisers were to be donated to provide medical supplies, school supplies and toys to children in need.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2008, Rihanna contributed to the song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Just_Stand_Up!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Just Stand Up! (page does not exist)">Just Stand Up!</a>" with fifteen other female artists, who shared the stage to perform the song live on September 5, 2008, during the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Stand_Up_to_Cancer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stand Up to Cancer (page does not exist)">Stand Up to Cancer</a>" television special. The proceeds from the single were given to the fundraiser.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> The television special helped raise $100&#160;million for cancer research.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup>
In 2010, Rihanna <a href="/wiki/Cover_song" title="Cover song" class="mw-redirect">covered</a> <a href="/wiki/Redemption_Song" title="Redemption Song">Redemption Song</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Marley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Marley (page does not exist)">Bob Marley</a>, it was released for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hope_For_Haiti_Now&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hope For Haiti Now (page does not exist)">Hope For Haiti Now</a> campaign in January 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup>
</p><p>On February 12, 2012, Rihanna performed a benefit show at the House of Blues in Los Angeles to raise money for the Children's Orthopaedic Center and The Mark Taper-Johnny Mercer Artists Program at Children's Hospital Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup>
In November 2012, Rihanna gave $100,000 to food bank donation for Hurricane Sandy,<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> the following month, Rihanna donated $1.75 million to Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Bridgetown, Barbados.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup>
In November 2013, Rihanna pledged £61,000 to UNICEF, to help the victims of the typhoon in Philippines.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup>
On January 3, 2014 Rihanna was part of the MAC Viva Glam campaign, which benefits women, men, and children living with HIV/AIDS.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Forbes_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forbes (magazine) (page does not exist)">Forbes magazine</a> began reporting on Rihanna's earnings in 2012, calculating that she earned $53 million between May 2011 and May 2012, for her music, tour and endorsements.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_226-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-226">[226]</a></sup> In 2013 Rihanna came in at number thirteen on the list with a total earning of $43 million due to endorsements such as vita coco.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> Rihanna's total net-worth is an estimated $90 million.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>On February 8, 2009, Rihanna's scheduled performance at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=51st_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="51st Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">51st Grammy Awards</a> was cancelled.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> Reports surfaced that then-boyfriend, singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chris_Brown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chris Brown (page does not exist)">Chris Brown</a> had beaten her. He was arrested on suspicion of making criminal threats.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> On March 5, 2009, Brown was charged with assault and making criminal threats.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Due to a leaked photograph from the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department" title="Los Angeles Police Department">Los Angeles Police Department</a> obtained by <a href="/w/index.php?title=TMZ.com&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TMZ.com (page does not exist)">TMZ.com</a>—which revealed that Rihanna had sustained visible injuries—an organization known as STOParazzi proposed "Rihanna's Law," which, if enacted, would "deter employees of law enforcement agencies from releasing photos or information that exploits crime victims."<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> Gil Kaufman of <a href="/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a> reported the "nonstop coverage of the Rihanna/Brown case has brought up a number of issues regarding the privacy of alleged victims of domestic violence, including the decision by almost all major news outlets to divulge the identity of the victim—which is not typically done in domestic-violence cases" and discussed the controversial distribution of the leaked photograph.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> Rihanna was subpoenaed to testify during a preliminary hearing in Los Angeles on June 22, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> On June 22, 2009, Brown pled guilty to felony assault. Brown received five years probation and was ordered to stay fifty yards (48 meters) away from Rihanna, unless at public events, which then would be reduced to ten yards (nine meters).<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> In February 2011, at the request of Brown's lawyer and with Rihanna's consent, Judge Patricia Schnegg modified with the restraining order to a "level one order," which allows the singers to appear at awards shows together in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>From December 2009 to 2010, Rihanna dated <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers" title="Los Angeles Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a> baseball star <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matt_Kemp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matt Kemp (page does not exist)">Matt Kemp</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> Canadian rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a> has also admitted to dating the singer.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> In a January 2013 interview with <i>Rolling Stone</i>, Rihanna confirmed that she had rekindled her relationship with Chris Brown,<sup id="cite_ref-telegraph2013_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-telegraph2013-313">[313]</a></sup> though he remained under probation for the 2009 domestic violence incident.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> The confirmation followed persistent media speculation throughout 2012 regarding the pair's reunion.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> In a May 2013 interview, Brown stated that he and Rihanna had broken up again.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_the_Sun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of the Sun (page does not exist)">Music of the Sun</a></i> (2005)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Girl_like_Me_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Girl like Me (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">A Girl like Me</a></i> (2006)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Good_Girl_Gone_Bad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Good Girl Gone Bad (page does not exist)">Good Girl Gone Bad</a></i> (2007)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rated_R_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rated R (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Rated R</a></i> (2009)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Loud_(Rihanna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Loud (Rihanna album) (page does not exist)">Loud</a></i> (2010)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Talk_That_Talk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Talk That Talk (page does not exist)">Talk That Talk</a></i> (2011)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Unapologetic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unapologetic (page does not exist)">Unapologetic</a></i> (2012)
</li>
</ul>

<ul>

</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Battleship_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battleship (film) (page does not exist)">Battleship</a></i> (2012)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=This_Is_the_End&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="This Is the End (page does not exist)">This Is the End</a></i> (2013)

</li>
</ul>

</li>

</li>
</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<dl>
<dd>1.<span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_a"><b><a href="#ref_a">^</a></b></span> Rihanna has won seven <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">Grammy Awards</a> as of 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup>  Despite conflicting reports, she was not the recipient of the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap_Song" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap Song">Grammy Award for Best Rap Song</a> award in 2012, since she was not a contributing songwriter.<sup id="cite_ref-All_of_the_Lights_official_Grammy_source_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-All_of_the_Lights_official_Grammy_source-319">[319]</a></sup> (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.grammy.com/artist/rihanna">Full list of Rihanna's Grammy Awards and Nominations</a>)
</dd>
</dl>

artists</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Fashion_designers" title="Category:Fashion designers">Fashion designers</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Female_hip_hop_musicians&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Female hip hop musicians (page does not exist)">Female hip hop musicians</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Grammy_Award-winning_artists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Grammy Award-winning artists (page does not exist)">Grammy Award-winning artists</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Hip_hop_singers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Hip hop singers (page does not exist)">Hip hop singers</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Juno_Award_winners&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Juno Award winners (page does not exist)">Juno Award winners</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Mezzo-sopranos" title="Category:Mezzo-sopranos">Mezzo-sopranos</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:People_educated_at_Combermere_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:People educated at Combermere School (page does not exist)">People educated at Combermere School</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:People_from_Saint_Michael,_Barbados&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:People from Saint Michael, Barbados (page does not exist)">People from Saint Michael, Barbados</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Reggae_fusion_artists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Reggae fusion artists (page does not exist)">Reggae fusion artists</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Roc_Nation_artists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Roc Nation artists (page does not exist)">Roc Nation artists</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Rhythm_and_blues_singers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Rhythm and blues singers (page does not exist)">Rhythm and blues singers</a></li><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:World_Music_Awards_winners&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1"
